Tom Holland is talented, but his Spiderman is my least favourite because has Lost everything that made him a true Hero: Uncle Ben, a real purpose by himself (not because he wants to be in a team), real Spidey powders not an Iron Man suit... It's not boring, but it isn't good either. Meh.

Author: kamin-987-808346
Review_Title: Looks like we'll get another reboot in a few years
Review: I've been a huge fan of Spiderman since I was a child. Grew up collecting all the comics and I have seen all the movies/cartoons. I have supported the reboots but it's now getting ridiculous.

Author: hoernkeem
Review_Title: Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017, Jon Watts) Spider-Man in MCU for reals now... great entry! great Peter Parker! great villain!
Review: Oh what's in a name. Homecoming for this latest Spider-Man incarnation obviously functions on a few levels the most glaring of which is the real world allusion to the fact that Spider-Man finally comes home under the umbrella of Marvel studios. Everyone seemed to understand that this would be high point not only for the studio but for Spider-Man as a film character as he has languished for years unable to get the right story and actor to truly make the character shine. To give credit though I think because of recent missteps we tend to think Spider-Man has never been good, but in all honesty Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire did the best they could in the first two volumes of Raimi's webslinger trilogy. Maguire, however, was never the ideal for the role and despite his best effort his very presence weighed the films down. 'Spider-Man 3' was an unmitigated disaster and the Andrew Garfield reboots further mired the character with bloated stories, labored special effects, lackluster villains and retreaded territory with yet again more Spidey origin story. 'Spider-Man: Homecoming' is an amazing film that not only revitalizes the character but also adds another interesting addendum to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Awesomely rolled out as a special guest star in 'Captain America: Civil War' Tom Holland's Spider-Man only hinted at the excellence to come. This film throws off the burdensome backstory and brings Spider-Man squarely back into the realm of high school. This is about as good as a PG-13 super hero flick can get and immediately earns a place among the best MCU films to date. And all this from a director (who is Jon Watts??) who has nothing on this level to speak of adding fuel to the fire that it is Kevin Feigie as producer that makes this world go round in the MCU and not necessarily the director. The film starts brilliantly with selfie videos from Peter Parker himself as he is whisked off with little information or fanfare to Berlin for his role in 'Civil War'. We get a hilarious recap of the battle from his point of view which does a great job of introducing us to the character but also reminding audiences that this Spider-Man exists squarely in the world of the Avengers. Post battle Stark lets him keep the suit that Stark designed and while Parker awaits a potential recall to the Avengers big leagues we see him being the friendly neighborhood Spider-Man as he does his thing on the streets of Queens. That in and of itself is telling as well as this film is kept for the most part in the working class section of NYC eschewing the glitz and glamor of Manhattan. We also see Peter interacting at school as the nerd he is hanging with his best friend and wistfully longing, perhaps somewhat creepily, as high school nerds are apt to do, after the hottest girl in school. Meanwhile we are also introduced to Adrian Toomes who is to become the villain Vulture. So much is good about Keaton and his portrayal of this villain who is much more grounded and relateable than your standard superhero bad guys. He seems like a man of our times, and very much a product of the current state of national affairs. He runs a salvage company that cleans up after super hero battles and when we first meet him he is cleaning up after the Avengers battle from the first Avengers film, but all of a sudden thanks to the government and Tony Stark the contract is ripped away from this seemingly good man and now his livelihood and family become threatened. Not only is his portrayal great he takes what could be a hokey villain and makes him intensely menacing. The look of the Vulture is perfect. It is also wonderful how they synced up Toomes' timeline right into the timeline of the MCU. It works so well! Toomes essentially starts a criminal enterprise stealing the alien tech that he was salvaging before and selling it on the black market. While Parker is waiting for his next big super hero break he stumbles across this villain and his criminal malfeasance in his own back yard and it seems to him that no one is listening to him so he takes matters into his own hands to stop the Vulture. The story works so well and the film makers do a great job of dovetailing Spider-Man into the MCU but also keeping him distinctly his own entity which becomes even more prevalent at the end of the film. There are hilarious cameos from Captain America reprising his PSA videos from back in the day. Also there is a twist in this film that, judging from audience reaction, no one even remotely saw coming. Thank God, at least for now, we had no mention of Uncle Ben, or great power and great responsibility or even Parker's photography or the Daily Bugle. There is only a small reference to his creation taken care of in one line of dialogue to his best friend and confidant. My actual problems with this movie are slight and really splitting hairs. The only off character for me was Zendaya's Michelle. She was just way to alternative and off putting with her too cool for school yet school is actually sorta cool mentality that I thought her odd appearances and short off kilter statements were jarring and a bit out of place in the overall narrative. The only other thing is I wish the final battle would've been a bit more of a bigger, intense set piece. The final battle seemed to happen very quickly and I just wanted more with some big flair shot to really capture that battle like the splitting ferry with Spidey suspended between the two halves really cemented that scene. And speaking of that ferry shot while it was very good it immediately brought to mind the iconic rail shot from 'Spider-Man 2' where Maguire was out in front of a runaway train and stopped using his webs and strength. To this day that remains probably my favorite scene and sequence in the Spider-Man series of films. It kind of surprises me that they would film a scene so similar in execution to that one. All of these criticisms can be taken with a grain of salt though. This film is truly magnificent and is great from the first frame to the last (and I do mean the last). There is full of content for causal fans and afficionados alike and with a little luck Marvel will be allowed to continue to make Spider-Man the marquis film character he was always meant to be. Hallelujah, the long dark night of Spider-Man's film soul is at an end.

Author: adamsmith-51004
Review: First of all let me start off by saying that I am a huge fan of Spider-Man and that he is one of the best comic book superheroes. After the very poor The Amazing Spider-Man 2 I suppose it made sense to give Spider-Man a reboot. I like many were excited by the prospect of Marvel being involved. Went to see this film with my brothers and after hearing only positive reviews went in confident of the fun being good. The film has some good points Tom Holland is very good as Peter Parker and Spider-Man and is very much like his personality from the comics. However, I can't say much more about the film positively. Spider-Man is and has nearly always worked alone so don't see the reason for iron man making him effectively his b****. According to this film iron man designed the famous suit. He also tells Spider-Man what he can and cannot do. Instead of Spider-Man being a hero finding his way it came across as him being stupid. In many of the scenes he messes up and te fight with vulture who once again in movie form we have to have a mechanical suit he ends up defeating himself. Also the amount of people in this movie that find out he is Spider-Man is ridiculous, first his best friend and then right at the end the very poorly cast aunt may. For anyone of my age who loved the original Spider-Man trilogy then this is way below.

Author: ivanmessimilos

It is true that this is a little younger Spiderman, so he is dealing with problems at school and obligations that the average high school student has. The big influence of MCU is visible, so the film looks like one episode, it bothers me personally. I also see how they made a setup for some things that didn't develop in that direction later, I mean certain bad guys. Some of the characters who are near Spideman did not like me because of the choice of actors. Of course, this is a purely subjective opinion.

Author: clarkejake
Review: This film is just a fun movie, a simple plot, a simple introduction for children fans of the MCU. Good characters but not particularly good character development.

Author: Mike_Devine
Review_Title: The reboot this franchise has been waiting for
Review: Disney's Marvel is a juggernaut unlike we've ever seen, as there is almost no end to the films the studio churns out of the comic book universe. So much so that they've resorted to rebooting franchises multiple times, with 'Spider-Man' now on its third reinvention of itself.

Author: ssnake_z
Review: SPIDER-MAN HOMECOMING

Author: jcallows
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming could've been great if it had been a stand-alone film. Instead, its constant references to the Avengers weighed it down. It's tied so closely to the Avengers it should've been called Spider-Man: The Seventh Avenger.

Author: andrew_flay
Review: Marvel milking it... This is my opinion, This film is some what entertaining and boring at the same time, it is also really predictable. If your a super hero fan you want be disappointed. It's a cliche type film.

Author: dfdieteman
Review_Title: Tom Holland good, most of the rest bad
Review: Spider-Man's characterization is radically changed in this film, picking up from Captain America: Civil War. Spider-Man is not the Peter Parker of the comics; he's a kid on a leash held by Tony Stark and Happy Hogan. The first tedious hour was painful. Aunt May is a fourth of her age in the comics. But Peter's childishness and the helicopter Stark and Hogan weaken the character. Overall, a disappointment. Michael Keaton is always good. It's a shame the script and direction wasted the talents of Holland and Keaton, and took such nonsensical liberties with Spider-Man's origins.

Author: xenoragnarok2012
Review: The action is good. The villain is awesome and great. Everything else is dreadful. The cast is a bunch of asinine nitwits. Tony Stark's presence is pointless and forced. Peter Parker is the whiniest child imaginable. The twist at the end is awful. The love interest looks like Michelle Obama. Flash Thompson is a squeaky laughable idiot. And Peter's friend is... annoying.

Author: cs_rahul_kumar
Review_Title: Spider-Man: Homecoming is a Fun Movie to Watch !!!
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming starts right after Spidey's unforgettable battle sequence in Captain America: Civil War, with our hero benched by Iron Man and told to lay low. Much as he wants to call himself an Avenger, he isn't part of the band. He got to play one gig nobody saw, and now he leaves too many voicemails. Meet Spider-Man, restlessly swinging around Queens, New York, his sloppy movements cut to music made by guys from that same friendly neighbour-hood. 'Hey Ho Lets Go' indeed.

Author: brian-ball
Review: This is the worst Spider-Man film to date. I thought Andrew Garfield's version was too goofy, but this one is a 100 times worse. The first 20 mins the film is all over the place. If this is supposed to be a reboot, then why haven't they started with how he gets his powers. It's so poorly acted, it feels like they are just rushing through the lines to get done with. The pace of the film is all wrong. Spider man seems to aged 12, wasn't he supposed to be a freelance photographer in the comics. It's just too stupid, what a mess and what a shame.

Author: RamonThomas
Review: This is the absolute worst Spiderman movie ever made. The main reason I dislike it so much is Tony Stark giving Spiderman his suit, which breaks the rules. In all comics and previous movies, being a smart student, he develops his own Spidy suit. This is a bloated attempt to connect him into the Marvel Cinematic Universe. And these films will never compare with the Tobey Macguire triligy.

Author: larrymeers
Review_Title: A fun and unique Spider-Man movie
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming focuses on the story of Peter Parker and how he has many responsibilities. He has to keep his grades up in school, he has to impress Tony Stark if he ever wants to become an avenger, he has to save the city from minor threats since he is spider-man, and he has to deal with a new threat "The Vulture".

Author: steamboy0
Review: I'm a big fan of Spiderman and I grow-ed up with this hero's comic books along with movies, animated TV series, etc. I had low expectations for this movie cause of knowing that D.J. as Iron Man/Tony Stark will be involved in along with the already known reworked char of aunt May, they transformed her from a sweet and wise old woman to a brainless "cougar"... But as a fan I went and watch it... Oh, well that was a huge mistake I made and truly regret it. Is a close adaptation of Ultimate Spider-man cartoon TV series, but in a worst way.

Author: targe1314
Review_Title: A mediocre addition to an already bloated superhero catelogue
Review: What has Marvel done to Spiderman?

Author: fa-599-726336
Review_Title: where are you taking this marvel?
Review: This movie is going under worst summer movies. Honestly, what was that? the dialogues were too predictable i almost finished all their sentences. It certainly lacked a plot. The only exciting parts for me were the scenes with Tony Stark or Zendaya, because their personalities are unpredictable so that adds excitement. It also feels like marvel is taking a different course because the target audience for this movie is definitely younger than usual.

Author: WondrousMoose
Review_Title: Fun and full of laughs, Spider-Man: Homecoming fits right in with Marvel's ever-expanding Cinematic Universe.
Review: It's been about a month since a major superhero film release, so here we are again!

Author: andrewroy-04316
Review_Title: Very fun, light movie and great performance from Holland, but third act struggles
Review: Spiderman Homecoming is a fun movie, and certainly worth watching. Holland does a phenomenal job and is charismatic and realistic in the titular role. The interactions and plot are reasonable, as the context and Parker were developed well. I did feel like many of the flaws that were lurking came out to full display in a lackluster third act. The villains were bland and didn't have any depth to them. As frequently happens, there were many implausible leaps, with Parker surviving and getting out of situations at will and the climax of the Avengers having 0 foresight and the bad guy thinks of everything, and then Parker takes the plane down by winning a fight with the vulture. His interactions with Stark also seemed a bit forced and not nuanced, with Stark being unambiguously angry and happy in the climaxes of the second and third acts, respectively. Parker's decision at the end also just seemed bizarre that he'd turn it down and not reach some sort of agreement. It felt like an attempt to show character development, but was just a "mature" decision contrary to what he had done to that point and was just a token decision to show a change. Many characters and elements of Parker's life were realistic and intelligently planned for, but the ending just felt like pure deus ex machina to make the Vulture seem unstoppable and then have Parker handily defeat it. Despite these issues, I did overall feel positively about it and found it enjoyable.

Author: tushargupta-27286
Review: ##$old spider man movie was more better then new spider man #$$but marvel is not ending for spider man because #$$$ $$,

Author: sufyaanrashid95
Review_Title: A Spectacular Addition to the Franchise
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming is an exhilarating addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe that is sure to delight fans of the web-slinging superhero. From the charming performance by Tom Holland as Peter Parker, to the thrilling action sequences, this movie is a true gem in the superhero genre.

Author: Otuoacheampong97
Review: What a movie to watch everything was great from start to finish.What makes this movie interesting for me is the directing.It was great in every aspect of the movie.The thrilling was felt,the adventure was also felt and the comic actually played its significant role.We deserved more and yes we've got it.

Author: silverstonevero
Review: I honestly am a big fan of spider-man. When they first (finally) introduce Spidey in CW, I was so excited and hoped to see more of this web crawler dude.

Author: gavinp9
Review_Title: Worthwhile reboot - fun, exciting and different enough
Review: 'Spider-Man: Homecoming' (or Spider-Man 6, technically) is Sony and Marvel finally playing nice and bringing Marvel's most popular comic book character into the MCU - will be interesting to see how he's involved in the upcoming Infinity War. A lot of people will ask "do we need another Spider-Man film?" The answer is, clearly "yes"! This is just as good as each of the other first Spider-Man films, and is different in that it's not an "origin story" - there's no Uncle Ben - and we've already seen Peter Parker (Holland) with his powers in 'Captain America: Civil War', so the film starts with a lot of momentum, where Peter's trying to impress Iron Man (Downey Jr.). Also, excellent use of the Ramones!

Author: connoralex
Review_Title: Refreshing take on a brilliant character
Review: Really enjoyed the latest incarnation of Spider-Man. It was refreshing to not have yet another origin story, as it allowed for more of a plot to develop, and room for the relationship between Peter and Tony Stark to grow throughout the film. I found the plot interesting and compelling. I particularly enjoyed the way that some of Peters challenges were portrayed, and what some of the issues would be when having such ability whilst still being in High School. Tom Holland provides an excellent and compelling performance as Peter Parker, and for me provides the boyish charm and nature I always imagined Peter would posses.

Author: angeltania
Review_Title: One of marvels worst spider man movies
Review: Better than black panther but still I thought is movie was going to be better

Author: alekspredator87
Review_Title: A new actor is an updated character
Review: It's no secret that Tom Holland joined the Marvel cinematic universe in the role of spider, when this superhero was already well known from the previous two series of films. And because of this, there were and still are some difficulties in his perception. Fans of superhero movies still remember Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield in this role. For this reason, it was more difficult for Holland. After all, you need to bring something new and interesting to your hero. And he coped by joining the already sensational franchise.

Author: jaredc-24231
Review_Title: Pennies and Dimes for a Bad Spidey Rhymes
Review: Fun, overdone, overconfident and so modernly influenced by this minute's culture, it'll lose currency within a day as the energy and corny Spidey dynamic sustains, with a few pokes and jokes along the way, but Homecoming is meant for gushingly-nostalgic High School Graduates and Prom Dates for this moment in time, but doesn't reflect or understand it's big picture impact and significance to the Spider-Man lore among the cinematic world for people to go back to. Bring us back to Spiderman 2 (5.7/10)

Author: lumiens
Review_Title: Saw the third reboot - it was okay.
Review: I took my wife and three boys to see the movie tonight. My boys gave the movie a ranking of 8-9 on a 10 pt scale; while my wife and I gave it a 7.

Author: TheMysteriousReviewer
Review: I never thought we would see the day MCU would actually make a Spider-Man film since we did get a couple that was played by Andrew Garfield in the early 2010s. But if I can be honest, I thought Tom Holland was better during that decade. Spider-Man: Homecoming is a really fun and really action-packed movie that introduces Peter Parker since Civil War. Not only would it introduce Spider-Man more, but it would include an engaging coming-of-age story about Peter's social life, outstanding visuals, characters that has given the Avengers franchise version of themselves, and awesome action to make the movie invested. This is a movie I recommend you should go watch if you're ever in the mood to watch a Spider-Man film. It is true that it wouldn't top as some other MCU films, but this has brought the trilogy to a great start.

Author: bdr-24502
Review_Title: Spidey copies Deadpool, tho makes more jokes!
Review: This was like the kid version of Deadpool. It's fast and hip and fun and there's some cameos. However, I could feel myself becoming more ADHD as the minutes increased towards the run time. The "man in the chair" bit was very fun. While the constant jokes were funny, the action was "seen-it-before" and so I would only give it 6/10.

Author: bononista
Review: The film was great,.... until you get to the part where Stark and Happy could have walked away but noooOooo For some Bizarre reason Pepper Potts shows up. The sequence makes no sense especially since she was written out of Age of Ultron and Civil War. Why is she back? Why is she there? Why is she in the top billing in the graphic credits and on the list and even listed here before all the other principle actors and actresses in the film? Why? Is she an Executive Producer? Why? Had they left her out and had Stark either not open the door (no crowd waiting as they implied) or opened the door (to go address the crowd), it could have been done without Paltrow. I went to the film for two things, RDJ and the Staten Island Ferry sequence. Tom did a great job in Avengers and in this, and his companion character is awesome as well. Keaton did an exceptional job. Why RUIN IT with the sudden appearance of Potts? Why? WHY? Yes go see it, its a great film.

Michael Keaton did his job as vulture as anybody could imagine he is my favorite spider man movie villein so far his performance was exceptionally good he was the perfect bad guy this young spider man kid could go up against. bad things about the movie was the story was predictable i could literately guess the next scene on some times some appearances was not that as like the hype was like Donald Glover's appearance. and the trailers gave away many parts of the movie anyway that was our fault watching them all not a perfect movie my ratings are 6.5stars looking forward to see the sequels

Author: info-426-168370
Review_Title: This is not a Spiderman movie
Review:
I was really exited to see the movie. But the whole movie is some kind of boring. There is no magic around Spiderman, no good enemies, no real plot or great characters. It's like a introduction of the new spider man for coming marvel films. That could have been done in 15 minutes. Skipping the standard - how spidey is born - start was a risky and interesting step, but because of this we do not get any information about it besides he was bitten by a spider.
The movie is ok to watch, nothing great or spectacular, and it is miles away from the spiderman films before.

Author: DawnOfTheRob
Review:
I went to see this one at the movies with my son.
It was ok, watchable, but definitely one of Marvel's weaker efforts. A bit lame at times, and nothing new really added. The main actor is likeable and did a good job with the script he was given. Which was a little less intense and maybe directed at a younger age group than previous efforts.

Review_Title: I liked everything about this movie... except spiderman.
Review: This movie had a good story, good characters, heck Iron Man was even likable in his cameo, the movie had a good version of the classic villain The Vulture. That said, spiderman was as annoying as he was in civil war (maybe even more so) the idea of spiderman being a kid about the age of the Runaways just isn't improving the character for me, also this entire reboot glossed over spiderman's origins even more then Batman's origins were in the Batman v. Author: Cool-Lion14
Review_Title: The next best thing next to the Avengers
Review: After watching the Sam Raimi Spider-Man trilogy and avoiding the Amazing Spider-Man duology, I'd heard about Homecoming. We get back to the roots of Peter Parker as the insecure high school student going about his life. This outdid the first Sam Raimi Spider-Man film (though I enjoyed that one the most before this one) and the villain was more relatable. This was the first time I'd seen Michael Keaton as a villain, after having been Batman/Bruce Wayne on two separate occasions under Tim Burton's direction. This gave us a second outing for Tom Holland's Spider-Man after Civil War. And Tony Stark wasn't bad either. This is one of Marvel's best MCU films along with the first Avengers. This was also my first Donald Glover film. Good work, MCU!

Author: mustermann_23
Review: As someone who had neither read any of the comics nor watched all Marvel-movies, I got to see a surprisingly (refreshingly) different movie from what I had expected. Having checked some of the 1-star reviews here I must say they are a bit misleading - whilst explaining valid complaints (especially from Spidey-fans) that I won't repeat here, they often highlight the performance of Michael Keaton as Vulture and mention other very positive points, which all summed up should not result in a 1-star rating.

Author: mieriks
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017) is entertaining, but not great, as a Spider-Man movie.

Author: davidpfalves
Review: O início do Spiderman numa versão óbvia mas com humor e ação.

Author: chriscarlisle25
Review_Title: It's a Wonderful Day In the Neighborhood for Spidey!
Review: I am going to keep this review short, sweet, and simple. This Spidey movie may be better than Spider-Man 2 in certain aspects. I really enjoyed both the action, and the acting. Tom Holland is great as both Peter Parker, and his alter-ego Spider-Man. You can really feel his anxiety, and empathize with him. Michael Keaton actually makes for a fantastic intimidating villain with his own moral code in this one. You both sympathize with, and despise the guy at the same time. I never thought I'd see the day where I actually would like Vulture. The rest of the supporting cast play their roles fairly well too; especially Peter's friend Ned Leeds. He is a funny side character with a few standout scenes of his own. There were a couple of scenes where I found myself chuckling. The action in this one is pretty stellar, and Spider- Man is exactly how he should be in this one. He is the wise cracking, swashbuckling teenage hero he was intended to be. The costume is better than any previous iteration in my opinion. This one made more sense in a lot of ways, and was more faithful to the comics. They even play an adaptation of his old cartoon theme! All in all, an amazing movie!

Author: claszdsburrogato
Review: Everyone always wanted to see Spider-Man along with the other superheroes in the Marvel universe, but after that happened a lot of criticism was made. Are these reviews really right? Some say this is the worst Spider-Man in cinema, but I don't think so. As much as it has the problem of being too much of an "iron boy" movie, it still holds up as a good Spider-Man movie. He has the character's charisma and manages to make good jokes, the biggest problem is Peter Parker. He seems not to suffer consequences and his entire school and family nucleus is very weak. The film's villain is its highest point, especially in the third act when it is revealed who he really is. This isn't the worst Spider-Man, as much as it has several problems, but it's still a good movie.

Author: YouTubeblack
Review_Title: A good peter Parker movie, but is it really a good spiderman movie?
Review:
Well I'm a huge spiderman fan and was eagerly waiting for this movie from MCU.
After watching spiderman trilogy and amazing spiderman movies, I can say that homecoming is an enjoyable peter Parker movie. Its defiantly better than amazing spiderman but is no way near to the 'spiderman 2'
Peter has all this stark tech which kind of overshadow the spiderman elements. The character development of the villain here is most important for a superhero movie, which i think was a bit off here.
Even when i see the train fight sequence from the spiderman 2, it makes me nervous and I care for spiderman, even though i have seen the movie like 10 times. The impact of that sequence shows who spiderman really is.
In spiderman homecoming, people on the ship are actually saved by ironman. I'm not saying its a bad thing. But as a spiderman stand alone film it was just like an introduction of spiderman in the MCU.
In a nut shell, Its an enjoyable movie but not as expected after reading the overrated reviews saying " it's the best spiderman movie ever "

Author: mr_bickle_the_pickle
Review_Title: Spider-Man, Spider-man, can MCU do it? Yes it Can!
Review: I think they have finally got the character of Spider-man right. He's a great mix of the nerdy, uncool Peter Parker we went and the cocky, quipping Spider-Man. And while they do great with him and give him a good character arc, I think they failed for the most part with other characters. Zendaya's Michelle shows up here and there to say a quip and then disappears. Otherwise she's mainly thrown in as a set up for a future movie. Aunt May doesn't have much to do in this film besides be the "hot Aunt" that everyone hits on. Donald Glover is in the movie for 2 scenes and he also is mainly there as a potential set up for a future movie. The only other character that I felt was decently fleshed out was Adrian Toomes (Vulture). I think they gave him some good backstory for why he hated Iron Man/The Avengers so much. And there were several good fights between him and Spider-man where he had the upper hand. And there was a really great acted, tension filled moment between the two of them in a car. And that's all I say about that scene because I'm trying to keep this review as spoiler free as possible. I think he was one of the better villains. The other weird thing I want to point out, is the timeline doesn't make sense. When we are first introduced to Vulture, its right after the events of the first Avengers (which was like 2012 I believe) but then it cuts to an "8 years later screen. Which either means this takes places in like 2020. Or The Avengers was taking place in like 2009. However, later in the film Happy Hogan makes a reference to something he's been holding onto since 2008 (which is when the first Iron Man came out). So......very confusing. I know some people don't like the fact that Iron Man built Spider-man's suit, but I think it makes sense for this universe and it does provide for a really funny scene once he gets the "training wheels" off and doesn't know how to use it because Tony went overboard with all the options. There is also plenty of other funny moments in the film, one of my favourites had to do with Ferris Bueller. I'm not sure how would I rank it amongst the other MCU movies. There's so many at this point, and I feel like I would have to do a re-watch. But, between the other MCU movie that came out this year, I think I enjoyed GOTG 2 a little bit more.

Author: tylerdburns-81322
Review: The twenty fifth entry into the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Spider-Man: Homecoming is a perfect reboot of a reboot of the character Spider-Man. The casting is once again at its best, as expected from the MCU. The humor in this film is some of the best the MCU has offered to date, even without the bonus of Robert Downey Jrs. Brief scenes. The special effects are breathtaking once again, with the plane scene near the end especially standing out. The character of Spider-Man is captured perfectly, with his awkward and wholesome self, and the humor, as stated previously, perfect. All in all, this film is a perfect Spider-Man film, and an amazing addition to the MCU. In just two appearances of Tom Holland as Peter Parker, he has established himself as the best Spider-Man to date.

Author: MickeyTheConstant
Review_Title: A Great Spider-Man but movie is a bit too aimed at kids
Review: Firstly the positives, Holland is a great Spidey, Keaton is a great baddie as the Vulture, Spidey's best mate is fun as is his younger Aunt May and the cameos from Stark and Happy are good. The movie is fun and feelgood. The negatives, there is only one really and that I just think it is aimed at a younger teen audience. I know Marvel superhero movies tend to attract a younger audience but this really goes for it. At times I thought, I am grown man and I am watching kids mess around at high school and fall in and out of love etc. I did enjoy it but not my favourite Marvel movie by far.

Author: tindfoting
Review: Not that I have any right to say it, since I with grace skipped the 2 with Andrew Garfield as Peter Parker, but based on my gut feeling and reviews, I'll think I stick to being stubborn and NEVER watched those two.

Author: undeaddt
Review_Title: Not the Spider-Man we love, but the Spider-Man we need.
Review: In all honesty, we all fell in love with the character that Toby built around Spider-Man, but in reality, that is not how the Spider-Man from the comics should be like. This is what he should act and look like and Tom Holland manages to make us see that on screen perfectly. The Vulture is also amazing because Michael Keaton is a movie legend and we had no doubt that anyway, but Tom Holland is the most positive surprise that MCU could've come up with. He is amazing in every way, the perfect kid to do the Spider-Man role. The movie is entertaining, it does not get boring for one second and keeps going with a fast pace all the way till the end.

Author: caseyferranti
Review: Saw the Trailer only. I have my favorites the first 3. The Trailer was enough to know it was too wishy washy. I'm sure Tom Holland is a wonderful Actor, but the way it was made it's not enough to get me to see beyond the Trailer. Sony... shouldn't have messed up after the first 3 installments. It's never the same when Companies change movies an alter what was good. While I enjoy Spider man and collect comic books I won't be seeing it anymore. Unless something drastically changes in the Movies

Author: dorazioandrew
Review_Title: One of the best Marvel movies
Review: Spider-Man Homecoming is by far one of the best marvel properties. It gives life back into the Spider-Man character and shows more of the friendly neighborhood Spider man approach with realistic scenarios. It has arguably the most dynamic, interesting, and threatening villain with the Vulture and fits nicely into the MCU.

Author: dolanSemicolon
Review: This is definitely not your typical Spider-man movie. Gone is the sentimentality of Maguire's movies, and also the mysteriousness of Garfield's movies. In this one, we get a Spidey that is young, inexperienced, and eager to please his mentor--no, not Uncle Ben--Tony Stark. After the events of Captain America: Civil War, Spider-Man is thrilled and wants to impress Iron Man. Unfortunately, in trying to do so, he gets into more trouble than he bargained for. You can't just call this a superhero movie, because it's visibly more than that. It's a coming-of-age teen movie, that happens to be about Peter Parker. We see our hero go through all the normal aspects of high school life: sitting alone in a cafeteria, asking his crush out on a date, the regular stuff. But, of course, it's a Spider-Man movie, so there's a lot of action, including a truly vertigo-inducing sequence involving the top of the Washington Monument. All in all, it's a step in a different direction for the Spider-Man character, but it's a welcome one.

Author: seruanyre
Review_Title: "With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility" - A Review of "Spider-Man: Homecoming"
Review: Spider-Man: Homecoming was a refreshing take on the beloved character. The film follows Peter Parker as he navigates the challenges of high school while also trying to be a superhero. Tom Holland does an excellent job of bringing a sense of relatability and vulnerability to the role of Spider-Man. The film also explores the theme of power and responsibility, which gives it a sense of maturity not often found in other superhero movies.

Author: emilyfrick-68723
Review_Title: A good marvel movie, however not true to the character
Review: I'll start off by saying that I did enjoy the movie, the storyline was ok and there were some new original points. Absolutely not a bad movie, but here comes my issue with it:

Review_Title: Better than I thought it would be
Review: Watched this because it was on Netflix. I'm not an adult baby so I'm not obsessed with these comic books movies like most people but I enjoyed this a lot more than I thought I would. So much so that I watched the second one, the following night. It's especially well filmed and the effects are about as good as it gets. This version of Peter Parker is exceptionally annoying though and I would very much like to slap the sound out of his name but Tom Holland does a pretty good job. Overall I'm very surprised.

Author: mardalsfossen01
Review_Title: Decent reboot with a very annoying Teen Spidey of the Marvel Cinematic Universe
Review:
Tom Holland acted well, he did what he was given. But he had to play a very annoying and immature teen Spider-Man and you can feel it's just a movie to introduce him in the MCU.
In the Comics he seems more like a quiet smart guy with glasses who wouldn't be as quirrly.
But maybe I am wrong about that.
I can definitely understand the image they are giving him here compared to already introduced Avengers characters. You just can't wait for him to grow up and not be as annoying.

Author: maharousewagdi
Review: The story is about a boy name Peter Parker who wants to help his mentor Tony Stark, with any superhero work. But Stark wants to keep him safe in Queens. So every night Peter goes out looking for crime to stop around the neighbor. One evening, he comes face to face with a group of ATM robbers armed with powerful, high tech weapons. Peter Parker detects dangerous gear for a gang led by Adrian Toomes, who is against the Avengers. Peter's quest to put an end to Tooms' dangerous game leads to a dangerous and surprising revelation, as well as a very annoying Iron Man.

Author: mrwayneint
Review_Title: Spider-Man Home Coming is a great Summer Blockbuster for all ages
Review: Spider-Man Home Coming Fresh from the advanced screening of Spider- Man Home coming, and I am still pretty hyped over how awesome this movie was. Let's just say Disney has done some justice to this character. Even though I have enjoyed all the other Spider-Man films (Including Spider-man 3 and Ultimate Spider-Man 2). The tone of the MCU is a perfect match for our young web swinger. If I were to compare this movie with any other Spider-Man film, I would say it's up there with Spider-Man 2 for sure. Tom Holland is a great fit and every character had a shining moment or two in the film. Michael Keaton, Michael Keaton, Michael Keaton! This man has single handedly saved the MCU from the dreaded villain curse. You want to talk about character development. Wow he gave a strong and intimidating performance as The Vulture. Peters best friend Ned, Aunt May, Tony Stark and even Happy the Butler all kept me glued to the Screen throughout the film. Now let's talk about the action. Very well paced action and pretty intense scenes, I mean you can tell that Peter was out of his league. Even the Shocker was pretty damn powerful and gave Spider- Man a run for his money. With MCU and the signature comedy lines it was well placed to make a pretty great summer blockbuster. The MCU does a great job with taking a genre and adding super heroes to it. For example Cap 2 was a espionage film and Ant Man was a heist film. Spider-Man Home coming is definitely a high school teen movie with a super hero twist. I give this movie 4/5 Mr. Wayne stamps for sure and highly encourage everyone to check it on the big screen. Spider-Man Home Coming out on July 7th.

Author: FelipeCarrillo
Review: In fifteen years, Sam Raimi and Marc Webb have been the only ones favored in adapting the comics of the amazing Spider-Man to live- action movies, one with more notoriety than the other, but, after all, both managed to be entertaining proposals with their dissimilar varieties. Anyhow, the successes didn't last long, causing the retention of Sony's projects to keep on making popcorn movies. Such time of rehab had an expiration date, exactly, until 2015, the year in which the film studio announced, with presumption, the deal with Stan Lee's production studio for bringing back the carefree hero from Queens, something that amazed both fans and Marvel Studios logical chronology as to the introduction of new characters, who will soon be present in the magnanimous American epopee par excellence, at least we hope that. The first step, Holland signing up, then Watts, later an extravagant number of screenwriters, Keaton as an antagonist, Michael Giacchino usual adding and the predisposed tools by the studio allowed the coming of the first great adventure of Spidey after his extremely short glance in the film of Russo brothers, "Civil War". And we're in luck, since its director takes the overblown mold of summer film away, in order to manufacture a coming-of-age movie portraying the day by day of one of the most well-liked and beloved superheroes of the MCU in a fascinating way.

Author: lmcressia
Review: This was a pretty good movie. It had humor, it had action, it had Robert Downey Jr. The CGI was a bit *off* in some of the swing-from- here-to-there scenes. Mostly I thought Michael Keaton did a great job. He played the part very well. Also, enough cannot be said about how they were able to take a character as lame as Vulture (seriously, is there a weaker repeat character in Spider-man's rogues gallery?) and make him ominous. The character had hat tips to the comic book character (flight suit collar looking sort of like the comic book Vulture's nonsense around his neck) without drawing too much from it -- which is a good thing, since comic book Vulture is lame. Shocker was in it... albeit in a secondary capacity. They also gave a nod to the comic book uniform for him, again without drawing too much from the on- page character.

Author: mariantambe
Review: Homecoming is decent at best. It lacks any sort of weight for the first two thirds of the movie and skirts around Spidey thinking about anything interesting. Take the beginning of the movie, for example. Spiderman is coming home from a civil war within the Avengers team where one side fought to imprison the other and a member of Spidey's team was shot down by friendly fire. He's not thinking about any of that stuff. No, he's acting like a kid who just got home from disneyland. He's excited, shooting videos, having a little commentary about how cool it it was. That sets the tone for the movie. Major events happen and he doesn't really think about them.

Author: DHWaldron
Review_Title: A teenage Peter Parker (Spider-man) is trying to find his way into The Avengers (a group of superheroes) and his way in the superhero world.
Review: With a new "Spider-man" (actor), as well as basically a whole new cast (apart from Iron Man cameos) I saw the new trailer for "Spider-man: Homecoming" and thought (despite being a fan of them): "How are they going to drag it out now?" Seems I was wrong. After years of "Spider-man" film adaptations, the origins have been redone by Andrew Garfield (2012) after they were adapted by Tobey Maguire, ten years earlier, with many of the memorable and interesting villains already being adapted. That's why I was glad to see no more origins. "Spider-man: Homecoming" is about Peter Parker trying to pair his social and superhero life together in the peak of adolescence. Meanwhile, Spider-man, his alter-ego/superhero identity, is trying to find his 'big break' in the superhero world, competing against a range of factors (e.g. school, love-life, age, etc).

And what's coming home got to do with it?

Author: mihai_aliman
Review: Marvel proposed another kind of Spider-Man, free from all the bad reboots. The film pictures Peter Parker, much younger than the previous versions, in an unexplainable and selfish attempt to catch the attention of Tony Stark (more on that later). He is still the nerdy, awkward, super smart teenage boy, but this time portrayed in a much racially diverse and politically correct environment: his love interest, Liz, is black, his best friend, Ned, is Filipino, his bully, Flash, appears to be of Indian origin. There are only hints of Peter's life up to this point, nothing very explicit. Not starting the story arc from the beginning might have been a good thing, nobody wanted to see Uncle Ben die again. But still, the Uncle played a very important role in the origin story, as the father-figure and the voice of reason acting as the decisive factor in Peter's coming of age. This adaption doesn't have such a figure. Aunt May, she too, much younger than previous films, is only the preoccupied mother-figure, with only general interest in her nephew, lacking any deep emotional connection with the protagonist. Happy Hogan, the appointed supervisor, doesn't seem to care about him very much, trying to constantly avoid talking to him. Tony Stark is the closest thing Peter has to a Uncle Ben, but their relationship is troublesome. We are somehow left to believe that the only interest Stark has in him is in building a new avenger. He gives him a suit and lets him learn how to use it, without offering proper advise or moral indication as to what it means to be a superhero what so ever. The hero is left to figure his stuff out, living with the ideal of being an Avenger, but without knowing the deep implications of engaging in a heroic act. If he should succeed, then Stark got himself a new weapon. If not, then he is to be stopped from pursuing the superhero business. This situation results in some moral ambiguity. In the previous adaptations, it was easy to distinguish the bad guys from the good ones. They did the generic bad guy staff (robbed banks, murdered innocent people etc.) either having no moral compass, or being controlled by evil forces. Peter was driven by stopping them for the greater good, himself being raised by his notorious relatives with a high degree of morality. But in this movie, the only reason of Peter being a hero is to impress Stark and be part of the Avengers. This selfish drive makes him even cherish when a crime is in progress, so that he can show off his skills. The villain, Vulture, is a mafia boss running an illegal gun factory that uses stolen alien technology. Because of this, we are left to believe he is the bad guy. His most despicable act is killing a disobedient subordinate (a bad guy himself). He is an avid entrepreneur, keen on keeping his business running and his family happy. He doesn't want to destroy the world, or take over the city with his weapons. He doesn't want power, and is afraid of law, especially the Avengers. This makes him an atypical villain. He is not the selfish one here, Peter is. Producing weapons and selling them is blameworthy, but then again, this is exactly how Stark made his fortune, with the only difference that he was (probably) selling them legally. Peter can't wait to take down any guy, and uses his power only with the apparent reason of doing justice, without thinking about the consequences. Any action he involves himself in turns out really bad, with numerous peoples life put in great danger. Without his implication, an ATM would have been robbed, some weapons would have been sold, and some alien artefacts would have been stolen. Wicked things, but without any direct civilian casualties. Peter is so disastrously bad at preventing those things that Stark is forced to confiscate his suit, the principal source of his powers up to this point. The selfish Peter is now gone. Without being an Avenger at stake, he can now rejoice in his normal urban life. He even manages to overcome his timidity and asks his crush on prom. The biggest moral dilemma so far awaits him. His girlfriends father, is the Vulture. He is offered the chance to do nothing. This would result in the stealing of alien technology and the commercialization of more weapons. He chooses to implicate himself once again, this time without the help of the suit. His drive is ambiguous. Impressing Stark is out of the picture, but standing down means he is a accomplice. It's important to mention that Peter doesn't really know what Vulture is up to at the moment he decides to intervene. This would 've been a great time to emphasize Peter's morality, but we are left wondering if he chooses to action just because he sees this as the opportunity to redeem himself in the eyes of Stark, or because he simply wants to do the right thing. I believe it was the first reason that really drove Peter. When he managed to track down Vulture and find out his plan, the wisest action in his situation would be to inform Stark or the police about it. Even if the Vulture would not have been stopped in that instant, Peter knew his identity and he could easily follow him and find out where he took the stolen cargo. Alone and without his suit, he stood no chance of defeating the villain safely. He somehow decides to do the crazy thing and stop him with his bare web, knowing that it would not have been such a big deal after all, if Vulture stole those artifacts. I think he does this just to prove himself again, and ends up crashing a plane dangerously near the city. It looks good, feels fine, but they messed up the plot with an unconvincing hero.

Author: domtaylor
Review_Title: Refreshingly low stakes and great performances make this the best Spider-Man film since 'Spider-Man 2'
Review: Easily the best 'Spider-Man' film since Sam Raimi's 'Spider-Man 2', Jon Watts' 'Spider-Man: Homecoming' is a constantly entertaining boots on the ground story, with refreshingly small stakes and a good sense of humour. Tom Holland is great as a young Peter Parker, one that actually acts and feels like a teenager, and his performance really keeps the film webbed together. Michael Keaton also gives a fantastic performance as Adrian Toomes. While the villain is rather generic, it's Keaton's performance that makes him a memorable one. The most interesting aspects of the story are seeing Peter Parker get to grips with his powers and begin to discover more about the dangers of the world and himself. The worst aspects of the film are actually the high-flying CGI action sequences as they feel entirely synthetic. It's a shame that they decided to make almost all of the action CGI, especially considering that Tom Holland is capable of performing stunts. In fact, he actually did do the majority of stunts himself, only the studio decided to make him do these while wearing a mo-cap suit, so that they could mimic his movements onto a GCI model. I personally feel like this was a bad move and that the action would have felt more realistic if they used an actual stunt team with Holland at the forefront. Still, the great character moments outweigh the somewhat unremarkable action scenes and the film contains one of the best, most tense scenes in the entire MCU. It's a scene in which in which there is no CGI involved, just two actors and a car. 8/10

Author: lmw-73369
Review: The movie was quite humorous and contained a good amount of action. It is a great coming-of-age tale, complete with love interests and a rebellious phase. It weaves in other Marvel characters without shifting the focus of the film. Only downside was that parts of it seem a little childish, but it all fit because the main character is in early high school.

Author: padawanmovies
Review:
*contains spoilers*I had no interest in seeing this in theaters for a multitude of reasons: Marvel movies won't miss my $(they make enough), I wasn't a fan of the Garfield versions so assumed I wouldn't like this, I'm not a Huge fan of comic book films. So I bookmarked this in my cable's onDemand function to watch at a later time... I was pleasantly surprised at how good this was. It took me awhile to believe Tomei could be Aunt May but I got past that. I thought Holland did a pretty good job and I really enjoyed Keaton as a villain (although I'm still slightly confused about his motives. He kept saying he was selling the weapons to criminals for his family. Seemed to me like he was just doing it to be rich). I also thought it was really funny w/o trying too hard to be so. All in all I thought it was pretty good and that they should stick with Holland for a few years. 
p.s. Ned was my favorite character, so adorable and funny! Thought he looked like John Popper from Blues Traveler when they went to the party!

Author: jglick3271
Review_Title: another superhero finding his place in the Marvel Universe
Review: This is a coming of age movie about a kid learning to be a man, as well as a webslinging superhero at the same time. Peter Parker, the template for high school awkwardness attempts to go from child to adulthood without concerning himself with the trials and tribulations that go along with this process. The movie itself is a bit refreshing in that we have an antagonist that most of us can relate to...an antagonist that would get ripped apart by Hulk or Thor, but can more than hold his own going toe to toe with the young "web head" who attempts to thwart his every nefarious move.

Author: jouford-38911
Review: Marvel: Stop cramming diversity down our throats.   Escaping from the endless barrage of "equality", and the perpetual and  aggressive whinging of its supporters is part of the reason I go to  movies. I don't want to be made to feel guilty for being a white,  heterosexual male whilst at the cinema as well as everywhere else in my  day-to-day life. Changing the gender and ethnicity of characters just  for the sake of being inclusive is ridiculous. If there's a reason for  it - fair enough. But there simply wasn't in this case. It was done  because the current mainstream narrative is that white males are  responsible for every ill on the planet, because ... reasons. So let's  urinate all over them here, too, to virtue signal to everyone just how  progressive we are. Total crap.  Tom Holland was very good as Parker/Spider Man. I also liked Jacob  Batalon as Ned. In fact, I was pretty impressed with all of the actors  in this film. Actually, if it wasn't for the performances, I was going  to score the film a 4. My issue isn't with the actors, it's with  liberal Hollywood and their obsession with inserting a "message" into  every film they produce lately.  This is the last big budget Hollywood production I'm going to watch for  a while. I want to be entertained, not miseducated.

Author: kane_1371-117-231060
Review_Title: Oh Spidey, stop it, you are killing me.
Review:
This movie is all over the place with its cringe element, the gags are out of control, the tone is always changing, the story is trying too hard and is not really being genuine.
Another thing I picked up was that Homecoming Spiderman is the worst Spiderman ever. If he was to go toe to toe with Spiderman 1 and the amazing Spiderman 1 spidermen he would get destroyed.
Just imagine all they achieved in their first movies, and overall mastery they had on their skills compared to this one and not to mention this wasn't even his first appearance!!!
This all comes down to the way Disney execs and writers handled the character.
Peter Parker one of the strongest most intelligent heroes of Marvel universe was a slave to his suit basically (and yes it was also mentioned kind of in the story about how he was too reliant on the suit but that is basically just trying to dampen the impact of a damage already done.)
Peter Parker is a brilliant mind and here we didn't have the chance to get much of that because what we were constantly getting was the suit doing all the thinking for Peter.
Peter is dumbed down massively and that is sad.
When Peter comes in contact with Iron spider suit in the comics he at first is excited but soon realises that it is not who he is and leaves it behind for his normal suit, that alone shows how much of a different character he is to what Homecoming Peter is.
This is also very unfortunate as Tom is a great actor, he is very fun to watch and I can believe his sense of wonder and joy but the movie plot drags him down too much.
So all in all not really happy with the way the character was handled.
The story needed more work but the visuals that wins a lot of points from me, there are a few imagery easter eggs, as in shots straight out of the comic books and they are basically eye candy and just beautiful.
I expected a lot more out of this movie after all the gloating about the fact that Marvel was going to do a good spiderman movie unlike the older ones. But well I am not actually surprised.

Author: dwankan
Review:
I've been watching the MCU films, and I've enjoyed most of them greatly despite their (expected) flaws. Unfortunately, this one doesn't work for me, I think mostly because I'm over the age of 17.
This film is mostly a standard, formulaic high school dramedy. In one sequence, the sidekick friend announces to their entire PE class that Peter knows Spiderman. This leads to a high school party scene (like every high school party scene in every high school movie you've ever seen) and Peter struggling with whether or not he should become Spiderman to impress the girl he likes. The sidekick friend is chubby but funny, the girl is pretty and clearly into Peter, but he's too shy to go after her, the adults just don't take Peter seriously, and in the film he was mostly struggling to find his self esteem.
I came into this for a super hero movie, not a Disney Channel series following the ins and outs of a quirky teenager's life problems, and this plays like a lesson-learning episode of a standard acculturation serial, the Marvel super-hero aspect playing second fiddle throughout to the believe-in-yourself-young-middle-class-person plot.
The movie does have a few good points: I like Michael Keaton in it, Tom Holland makes a good Peter Parker even if he gets a little annoying sometimes, and it adds some (albeit shallow) depth to the MCU.

Author: SebMoz
Review_Title: It's fine, it's alright, it's whatever
Review: Spiderman: Homecoming is the first Spiderman movie in the MCU, and to be honest, I don't really have any strong opinions of what-so-ever. It's most certainly not an incompetent film, as there are plenty to like about it. I really enjoy Tom Holland as Peter Parker, and Peter himself was pretty well written, with a nice character arc. I will say that even though we already got Spiderman's introduction in Civil War, the movie felt a little empty without a proper origin story. We never saw Peter struggle with his powers, nor did we get a lot of character establishment to make him more relatable. This could be said for a lot of characters in the movie, none of them felt like they had a lot to do, apart from his best friend, the villain, and Tony Stark. Michael Keaton did a pretty good job as the villain, and while his character at least had understandable motivations, I'm still not sure how wanting to protect your family leads to becoming a thief and a murderer. The movie is fairly well directed, even though there was nothing particularly outstanding about it. I also think that the movie isn't paced very well, it was a bit too slow particularly in the first half. That being said, the second half was really enjoyable and I was very entertained. The action was good, the characters were fine, and the plot itself is nice and simple. Overall, this is just a very average, decent film, that's not special in any way. Still, I mostly enjoyed my time, and while it's not among the best movies in the MCU, it's still a good time that I don't regret subjugating myself to.

Author: rs403404
Review_Title: Simple Fun and a Little More
Review: Kevin Feige has been doing a phenomenal job with the Marvel Cinematic Universe since the original "Iron Man" over nine years ago. All the movies have at the very least been serviceable and sometimes he even manages a real homerun like the Captain America series, "The Avengers", "Guardians of the Galaxy", and the aforementioned "Iron Man". The only Marvel superhero franchise that hit the same quality levels as the MCU is the original Spider-Man trilogy directed by Sam Raimi. Specifically the first two, though the third does have its strengths.

Author: hanshotfirst-20216
Review_Title: Excellent Movie; Ranks Amongst the Best of the MCU
Review: Great movie! It successfully balanced drama, action, and humor. Most of the jokes, while predictable, are hilarious (especially the post-credits scene, which is too good to spoil). The action sequences, while slightly overstuffed, are excellent, and while this movie uses a ton of CGI, it is good CGI. Performance-wise, all of the actors are excellent. Tom Holland is amazing as both Peter Parker and Spider-Man, showcasing Parker as a convincing ultra-geek/nerd and Spider-Man as having slightly more confidence than Parker, but still as a hero who is still convincingly inexperienced. The Vulture/Adrian Toomes is not the greatest movie villain as a character, but Keaton's performance as Toomes is the best performance of the movie, and quite possibly of the MCU. The musical score is excellent. I only have three points of criticism: 1. Flash Thompson is a proved jerk in the movie, but he does not have enough screen time for the audience to absolutely despise him. 2. Michelle does not have enough screen time to be anything but simply there. 3. There are too many villains, and their operations are too complex to be understood in a single viewing. Still, a great movie, and I would give it 9.5 or 9.75 stars instead of 9 if I could.

Author: carrotstix
Review_Title: Good but the characters just weren't there
Review: However colourful, witty and truly entertaining Spider-man Homecoming was, I felt that it was missing something vital when compared to its predecessors. Perhaps Marvel was trying too hard to make this movie different from the previous installments, but the characters felt watered down and almost boring. None of the relationships that are supposed to define Peter and help us empathize with him are there. Instead, characters like Flash, May and even his best friend are used for setting and comedic relief. Next, there was much too little context for Peter's life. I don't need a whole 30 minutes dedicated to a new take on the origin story, but without any background, this version of Peter Parker comes across as a bit bland. He's basically just a regular kid with a good moral compass. My last point is purely opinion regarding the role of Tony Stark. Yeah, he's an awesome character, but he played what was literally the biggest safety net I ever saw. Spidey's whole shtick used to be about him learning the ropes himself through trial and lots of error. Now that he has this mentor character to wipe his butt, Peter comes across as something of a whiny, reckless kid who just stumbled into his rebellious phase. Anways, overall, pretty solid movie with cool action sequences and a satisfying plot. Tom Holland made a pretty good Spider-man ass well. But in the end, I definitely wasn't as emotionally invested as I wanted to be.

Author: detodounpoco
Review: I've been a fan of Spiderman since Tobey's film came out. Since then, I've always loved to watch the movies of what is probably my favorite of Marvel superheroes. There's just one problem, they were always missing something. Spiderman: Homecoming changed that. Not only is it a great movie overall, filled with action, lots of comedy (let's not forget amazing scenes between Holland and RDJ), and even a little romance. But it finally gives fans the perfect combination of Peter Parker AND Spiderman! Tom Holland's performance is real and authentic, giving the audience a 15yo who is having the time of his life being a superhero. He fails, and makes mistakes. He doesn't know the meaning of limits and believes he can do anything as long as he has the suit. However, he is charming, and sweet, and gets nervous around girls and he LEARNS in time what it really means to be a hero! Yes, the movie has flaws, but they all do. Homecoming is beautifully done, and amazingly written. It introduces a new generation to Spiderman, the friendly neighborhood hero, in the most accurate way possible. It stays true to the comics and to who Peter Parker really is. I can't wait to see Peter's next adventure and encourage everyone to go see this movie! Definitely one of Marvel's best! Wanna read more? Check out my blog --> detodounpoco506.wordpress.com

Author: jackstonestone

Great message and lessons to be taught, good taste in music selection and having a very rhythmic and catchy theme for spiderman whenever he does something heroic on screen. Fun story and is a great start for peter as a character dealing with having two different lives. 10/10.

Granted, Sam Raimi's movies were great action movies that arguably propelled the boost of live action comic book adaptations in the early 2000s and The Amazing Spider Man entries were entertaining enough but Marvel studios have really nailed the character of Peter Parker in this ironically fresh entry, even at the sacrifice of a more action heavy structure.

Author: gsurveil1
Review: I'm not going to beat around the bush so let's get to it. Spider-Man Homecoming was "cute". It's exactly what you take your toddlers to see and all is well. The problem is that this film was boring for the most part. I couldn't believe this was the same Spidey that kicked everyone's tail in Civil War. In this film he was clumsy to the point of ridiculous and he didn't improve much through the film til the end. Holland is a good Spider-Man but the script held him back. The saving graces were Stark, Happy, the talking suit, Aunt Mae and of course Michael Keaton. He stole the film. No way could this Spider-Man could have gone toe to toe with Keaton's Vulture. An interesting twist towards the end was so impressive no one saw that coming. Still it wasn't the Spidey I expected especially with his predecessors Tobey and Andrew. It was alright but not on par with any MCU films. 6/10. Bring on Black Panther!

Author: rolandjordaan2
Review: Arguably one of the most anticipated films since the start of the MCU 9 years ago, this was mostly worth the wait. Tom Holland shines in the title role, bringing a new charm and vulnerability to the character that was lacking in the earlier portrayals by both Toby Maguire and Andrew Garfield. The film itself is far removed in both tone and style from what we have come to expect from the other films already released in the MCU, being just as much a teen comedy as a superhero film and switching well from being mostly comedic to sometimes surprisingly dark. Michael Keaton does an excellent job bringing the Vulture to life, keeping the character eerie, yet at the core still slightly sympathetic. Although the high school plot line and antics do get tiring at times, they are not enough to spoil what is generally a very decent and thoroughly entertaining film.

Author: cmpatterson-86493
Review: The MCU has faced many challenges over the years, but the difficulty this time around was creating a successful reboot to a character we've seen portrayed by three different actors in a 15 year period. "Spider-Man: Homecoming" unexpectedly holds its own and succeeds by not attempting to retell the origin story yet again, and by casting an actor who portrays both Peter Parker and Spider-Man in a very likable manner. Our hero is very much in training mode at this point, but the journey is fun regardless. Marvel can rest easy knowing they have created not just a fun Spider-Man film, but also a humorous coming of age tale revolved around a boy finding his place within his own circle all while being a superhero. #spidermanhomecoming

Author: manymilesaway
Review_Title: A blast - Just one we've had before
Review: Like most of the MCU catalogue, Homecoming offers its fair share of solid action scenes, funny moments and is perpetuated by a good score and strong performances from the main cast. The story however is mainly just following the same formulaic structure that we have come to know and expect from the vast majority of today's superhero films. It's a structure that quite clearly works, but the lack of originality just makes it feel like we're watching the same product re-branded with a few new gimmicks thrown in over and over again. Despite this its still a greatly enjoyable watch - just not one that feels all that new.

Review: I personally really enjoyed this movie. It was a good laugh and a great time overall. Of course, I might be a little biased, because Spider-Man is my favorite character of all time, but this movie wasn't bad at all. I liked, that they kept it small-scaled with the first one. Especially after watching "Spider-Man: No Way Home", I found some new meaning and liking to this film. The Vulture is a great villain with a good connection and relationship to Peter. Iron Man was a fun addition in this film, and he caused a lot of the laughs in this movie. I loved the final act, because Peter had to prove himself. Sure, Lizzy wasn't a good love interest, but she didn't really need to be. I didn't love, what they did with Flash, but those are all minor details. The best part about this movie was Peter's and Ned's friendship. They are absolutely hilarious together. Overall, this movie is a blast, and if you are a Marvel or Spider-Man fan, you will like it.

Author: alanahsurfchick
Review_Title: Best Non-Origin Story For Spidey By Far
Review: Tom Holland returns as Peter Parker/Spider-Man in his first solo outing. Following the events of Captain America: Civil War, Peter returns to his everyday high school life whilst juggling his responsibilities as Spider-Man. Wanting to prove himself worthy of becoming an Avenger to his mentor, Tony Stark/Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Peter efforts cause him to stumble onto the criminal activities of new super-villain, Vulture (Michael Keaton). Peter must now battle this new threat and, along the way, he might just show everyone that even a teenager can save the day. In my opinion, this is the best non-origin story Spider-Man film so far. Even though it a part of the MCU and makes references to previous films, this movie doesn't use what's come before as a crutch. It tells its own story and avoids being little more than a set-up film. It also twisted in ways I was unprepared for and left my jaw slacken for several minutes after the twist had actually occurred. Tom Holland does an excellent job as both Peter and Spidey. His character loves the thrill of being Spider-Man, but struggles with being regular Peter Parker. He's a fun hero but he's far from perfect, which is what makes him relatable. The supporting cast are also add a lot of flair to the film, from Peter's geeky best friend, Ned (Jacob Batalon), to Peter's caring Aunt May (Marisa Tomei). Now, there are a couple flaws, like the film hardly making any references to Spidey's spider sense power. I also wanted a few more scenes of Zendaya's character, Michelle, a quirky classmate and friend of Peter's who has a sarcastic wit that I found rather entertaining. In the end though, Spider-Man: Homecoming was a fun film with enjoyable action sequences and an entertaining cast. By La Reviews For more reviews please check out La Reviews at lareviewscom.wordpress.com

Review_Title: A lighthearted take on a well worn costumed superhero
Review: This is the third incarnation of Spider-Man in the past 15 years, so it was always going to be an uphill battle to make it fresh and exciting to audiences. Quite wisely, director Jon Watts plays 'Spider-Man: Homecoming' for laughs and scales down the world-ending threats to craft a more intimate and quirky comic book adventure with street- level stakes. Thanks to the lightness of tone and the quirk of the characters, the film mostly succeeds, even if the plot never rises above the mildly diverting.

Author: jdr_ph
Review: Okay, I know I am an old Asian fart, but I don't care how many millennials feel about Raimi's versions. For me, Spiderman 1 and 2 are still the best and until now the scenes of those movies are very memorable. Not everything is CGI or costumes or realistic lines. For me,superhero movies should not take themselves seriously but at the same time not be a bag of jokes all the time. I really wanted to give the new versions of Spiderman some chance. I watched Amazing Spiderman and regretted it so I didn't watch the second of that supposedly trilogy. For this latest version, I was hoping against hope that the detractors were just mostly DC fans so I gave it try. Turned out to be that many Spiderman fans like felt that a lot of things were forced, especially the diversity issue (And I am Asian). I am not pro-DC or pro-Marvel. I have my favorite superheroes from each universe. This movie just shows me that Raimi really left a mark. The fact that they made the villain the father of someone close to Peter's heart felt like Spiderman 1 all over again. I get it that the new generation may want something different but for me, there is nothing wrong with sticking to one's race if the writer is white with his own point of view in the first place. As an Asian, I don't think a remake of ONCE UPON IN CHINA needs a black kung fu master, a white bald kung fu sidekick or a South American gay love interest to make it a good film that represents almost all nationalities. I am tired of the PC culture. I am not watching a political show. We cannot represent everyone in a movie. And I don't mind if the race is homogenous in a movie, especially when the era represents a certain period. Good thing that NYC is quite diverse so in this movie it is acceptable but, still, we know the hidden agenda why these different nationalities were present in this latest version of Spiderman. Just like blacks became equal citizens of 19th century French society in BEAUTY AND THE BEAST when they were actually slaves at that time. Art should not always try to be political even though some artists are political in their approach. However, there is also the art for art's sake point of view. That is why I am rewatching old films and TV series on YT nowadays because I feel that they have more to say about life in general than what I am seeing now which tends to be about the same issue about diversity and being PC. Good Grief!

Author: tdub154420
Review_Title: It's got charm, wit and style - just missing heart.
Review: In Spider-Man's fifth appearance on the big screen they chose a very different approach for his character and it pays off greatly. Peter Parker is a humble teenager who just can't wait to be a superhero. His conflict is that he has been deemed by his hero and mentor,r Iron Man, as merely a "superhero in training". Taking influences from John Hughes movies of the past, Marvel tells a teen movie as best they can. The only issue is that it is too "super" to truly embody the spirit of John Hughes films. Director/writer John Hughes films succeeded because he so well understood the ethos of adolescence, from teenage insecurity to high school hopes and ambitions, John Hughes had an innate sense of how teenagers ticked and how to make his teenage characters emotionally relatable. Its hard to tell a story that is emotionally relatable when its about a teenage boy who has been recruited for something so great. It may be relatable to the likes of Lebron James, who couldn't wait to be drafted to the NBA out of high school, but for most audience members Spider-Man's conflict could come off as less-relatable - or at least less emotionally significant. And therein lies the biggest issue with this movie: it seems to lack heart. Spider-Man is driven by wanting to be taken seriously, by wanting to be a real superhero. In climatic moments his emotional motivation is just to not let down his hero Tony Stark - rather than being driven by any deeper personal commitments to loved ones or any intimate personal reasons. Its a main plot that does drive character development, but its so lightweight of an emotional anchor it seems like it would work better as a subplot. In some ways this is a nice change of pace for a superhero movie, but there are some scenes in which the film tries desperately to drum up emotion and hearken to the heart of the film, and its these scenes that just feel empty and shallow. But for the rest of the film its light on its feet. It is charming and Tom Holland and his supporting cast of teenage friends are a joy to watch. My only hope is that going forward they are able to find a deeper, more relatable emotional heart for Spider-Man's story.
